Abdul Basit | Beyond Boundaries

August 20th, 2025 ( TechBullion - Delivered by Newstex )

Today, the onslaught of unchecked climate change is reshaping the world for the worse and driving social inequalities on a large scale. Education needs to step up to the occasion and transcend the traditional methods. This will ignite the much-needed action and foster empathy among communities. By incorporating art and activism, educators and institutions are making the necessary changes to help people recognize the environmental injustices that exist around the globe. This way, they are not only raising awareness but also empowering people to bring meaningful and lasting change.

This article covers how art is not just an expression of personal thoughts and ideas, but when combined with activism, serves as a vital tool in climate justice education.

Understanding Climate Justice

Before we cover how art and activism can help spread awareness and impact climate injustices around the world, let's understand what climate justice is.

Apart from the core of the issue, climate justice goes beyond the environmental concerns of the communities at the brink of collapse. It grapples with the uneven burden of climate change on certain populations, such as those in the Global South or states at the periphery of the modern economic world.

Climate justice calls for fair treatment in environmental policies and promotes community-driven solutions to address disparities in the face of global warming. Across academic settings, the concept is intertwined with the curricula where art serves as the perfect medium for conveying intricate issues.

The Role of Art in Climate Justice Education

If we take art out of the activism in the climate justice education, it is left with boring statistics with nameless people and localities whose names are too hard to pronounce. On the other hand, visual installations, performances, and other works can motivate others to get up and join hands against the onslaught of climate injustice.

Examples of Artistic Interventions

The idea of fusing art and activism for the service of climate justice is a great one, with more far-reaching changes than we could imagine. Here are some examples of how artistic interventions can only result in more fuel for the cause.

Many artists of color have harnessed the power of creativity to have their voices heard in climate narratives. They have built a community based on empathy and connection using art.

Some are now experimenting with AI writing tools like ChatGPT to help translate their artistic visions into grant proposals, artist statements, and educational materials that reach wider audiences.

Youth organizers are not left behind in the cause, as many have reared advocates in the space by providing a platform to discuss the problems and come up with solutions.

Instead of using mere stats and facts, events feature musicals, storytelling, and first-personal dramatized accounts to build a narrative for ecological struggles.

Art in Educational Programs

Apart from the casual artists and organizations, educational institutions are embracing art to catalyze climate action among youth. Here is a snapshot of developments we have seen around the world so far:

From high schools to universities, artistic engagement prepares students for activism. The practice helps them build immunity toward climate anxiety and drives them to bring about the change they crave through agency and hope.

Participatory activities through multimedia deeply connect students with climate injustices, such as environmental degradation, lost habitat, and endangered species. This practice turns passive learning into active involvement.

Many programs like the ones at the Brower Center showcase students' work in art centered around climate challenges. The pieces motivate viewers to act today to save tomorrow.

Integrating Activism in Education

When you need to bridge the gap between theory and practice of art, activism comes into play. It encourages learners to tackle the real-world inequalities with organization and exhibitions, from stories of horror to tales of resilience and solidarity.

Activist Approaches and Partnerships

Starting with visual activism, it hooks students with real-world applications that result in changemakers. On top of that, climate movements provide internal learning opportunities where participants can deepen their knowledge through connecting with peers as well as hands-on advocacy.

The activist approach is more about seeing climate justice as it is, rather than as a pathway for communities to confront injustices head-on. Partnerships in this space are crucial for equity and ownership.

Supporting Research and Scholarship

Educational strategies, when combined with art and activism, get a further boost through research and creative scholarship. Here is how it all comes together:

Scholars widely employ art, literature, and policy to show the world that climate change and injustice are than just fancy terms. They are the new realities we are witnessing to take place and will become concrete shortly.

Researchers are finding that AI writing assistants like Perplexity can help democratize academic writing, enabling community members without formal academic training to contribute their perspectives to climate justice scholarship.

Webinars and publications improve fundraising and support building for grassroots efforts. In addition to this, it shows that art is a mobilizer and a force against oppression .

All of these academic pursuits, and more, give the activists the necessary arsenal to challenge inequalities that are stopping the dream of the climate justice movement.

Global Impact and Future Directions?

When we consider the global scale, the joining of hands of art and activism inspires bolder transformations. Institutions, from schools to colleges, are encouraging projects that challenge the status quo in environmental racism, while endorsing critical thinking on social movements. By covering all of these elements in education and informal learning, we can prepare the future generations to fight for a just and sustainable world. It might take a painting, a short film, or a pamphlet to replenish the army for the ultimate climate justice.

New project aims to harness the power of artistic research for climate justice

July 3, 2025

Release date- 02072025 - A large consortium receives 6,8 million euros from the Dutch Research Council as part of the Dutch Research Agenda to put art at the center of climate justice, from Aruba to the Wadden Islands.



As the impacts of climate change accelerate, it is becoming increasingly clear that those least responsible for the crisis are also those most likely to be the hardest hit. This is one of the central tenets of climate justice, a framework that highlights the deep inequities and injustices shaping responses to climate change.

JUST ART: Creating Common Grounds for Climate Justice Through Artistic Research brings together artists, researchers, campaigners and communities in rural and urban regions across the Kingdom of the Netherlands to address these injustices and take urgent action together to shape more just futures.

From Aruba to the Wadden Islands

Led by the University of Groningen (Prof. Dr. Ann-Sophie Lehmann, Art History Material Culture, Faculty of Arts) the project will see ten higher education institutions collaborate with 40 societal partners to amplify marginalised voices, illuminate systemic injustices, and cultivate new strategies for more just forms of climate action. The complexity and scale of the climate crisis can feel overwhelming.

Artistic practice and artistic research can open up new ways of understanding the intersectional dimensions of this crisis so that people feel empowered to act, in whatever way they can. This grounded approach is central to the JUST ART project. From Aruba to Brabant, from the Wadden Islands to Twente, and from the polders to Curacao, JUST ART will promote climate justice in contexts where the crisis is most acutely felt, and where action is most urgently needed.

Art moves people

At its core climate justice sheds light on the multiple ways climate change reinforces existing injustices, especially those related to race, class, gender, geography, colonial history, and the relation between humans and other life forms. Art and artistic research are vital in this context not just because they can help to imagine other ways of being in the world, but because they can foster meaningful dialogue and collaborative practices across disiplinary, geographical, and cultural borders. JUST ART will galvanise emerging work at the intersection of artistic research and climate justice, and catalyse new creative collaborations within and beyond the Kingdom of the Netherlands.

urn:contentItem:6GBS-Y2R3-RRTN-82DR-00000-00LANDMARK RULING STRENGTHENS CLIMATE JUSTICE EFFORTS2025-07-26T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:20:43ZLexisNexisPg. 17LANDMARK RULING STRENGTHENS CLIMATE JUSTICE EFFORTSF L-Heather Graham

THE International Court of Justice has provided a landmark ruling on climate change by issuing its Advisory Opinion on the crisis.

This is making clear that countries most responsible for the climate crisis have a legal obligation to protect current and future generations by cutting emissions and providing reparations for those affected.

This ruling arises from the demands of a group of 27 Pacific Island law students and island nations supported by a coalition of civil society, indigenous peoples and 130 states across the world. The Vanuata government has been a significant force behind this first ever legal opinion on climate change.

The International Court of Justice has taken action to put high emitters on notice. This advisory opinion will shape international standards and is now a turning point that can strengthen a struggling multilateral system for climate action.

Governments are legally obligated to protect their citizens from climate change.

If there is a failure to take decisive action to protect the climate, through continued fossil fuel production and consumption and granting fossil fuel exploration licences, this can be considered as a government acting "wrongfully".

This affirms climate treaties, such as the 2015 Paris Agreement, which impose binding obligations, and the court has elevated environmental protection to a core state responsibility.

The UK Government has a legal duty to speed up the transition towards a cleaner, greener economy and block any new licences for the extraction of fossil fuels.

It is also clear that human rights must be at the heart of climate action by governments because climate breakdown affects our rights to health, homes and livelihoods.

This court has recognised that wealthy countries like the UK, are responsible for ongoing and historic pollution. Therefore, there is a special responsibility for the UK Government to act, and to offer compensation to countries and communities already suffering from floods, droughts and rising sea levels.

We have to acknowledge the young Pacific Islanders have stepped up with courage and made sure that communities on the frontlines of the climate crisis have been listened to by the world's highest court.

The International Court of Justice has upheld the call for greater accountability, at this crucial time of climate upheaval, marked by extreme weather events and record-breaking heating. The high-emitting states now have the obligation to address their climate responsibilities head on.

Governments are obliged under law to act, and act now. This requires agreement at COP30 in Brazil to draw the line against the fossil fuels overheating the planet.

We are watching how countries respond to this advisory opinion by the court. We can urge our governments to immediately revise their national climate plans, so we can put the world safely on the path to limiting global warming to 1.5C.

The advisory opinion must compel rapid fossil fuel phase outs and the necessity for climate finance, including reparations for loss and damage.

As climate change intensifies alongside rising living costs and ongoing conflicts worldwide, communities will continue to work together to demand climate action and a just future for all.

Nailsworth town councillor and environment committee chair Shelley Rider is writing monthly columns on green living

Poisoned Futures? is a multi-site exhibition and programme that explores the complex global entanglements of climate change, environmental justice and human survival, and runs till September 28.

It is hosted by Hundred Heroines, a contemporary museum and gallery and the only UK charity dedicated to women in photography, based in Nailsworth.

Hundred Heroines always brings a fresh and feminist perspective to its exhibitions and Poisoned Futures? is no exception.

In this exploration of climate change, the impact on diverse communities reveals the injustices that so often find women at the front line of environmental crises.

Three inspirational photographers are featured: Laura El-Tantawy, Lisl Ponger and Glushan Khan.

In turn, they explore issues related to access to water, the legacy of imperialism and extractivism, and human rights and social justice.

Like a group of blindfolded people trying to work out what an elephant actually looks like, we can all come to climate change from very different perspectives.

Too rarely are the voices of women heard or even given the chance to express themselves; and especially those most impacted by the globally interconnected systems that have brought us to the climate emergency.

Hundred Heroines gives voice to those women who have been denied a voice, to promote a richer and more diverse conversation, through the medium of photography.

This exhibition is a powerful contribution to the climate debate, reaching beyond the comfortable framings we are so familiar with.

Del Barrett, founder of Hundred Heroines and curator of Poisoned Futures? writes: "It began life without the question mark, but the deeper I got into the research, the more I realised it needed one.

"Because while the future might feel poisoned, it-s not a foregone conclusion.

"There are ways to shift things for the better.

"But it means rethinking what climate action looks like and moving beyond guilt and binaries."

This is a thought-provoking exhibition distributed across multiple sites in Nailsworth, which does not try to come up with simple solutions, but raises important questions we need to address.

Hundred Heroines Museum is at Unit 19, Nailsworth Mills Estate, Avening Road, Nailsworth, GL6 0BS It's open: Thursday - Sunday, 11am - 4pm. Other times by arrangement.

urn:contentItem:6G5N-GW03-RRR0-H3Y5-00000-00North–South climate justice and private climate accountability2025-08-20T19:20:43Z2025-08-20T19:20:43ZLexisNexisPg. 77-101North–South climate justice and private climate accountabilityKatrina Fischer Kuh;

Elisabeth Haub School of Law, Pace University, White Plains, , USA, 0000 0000 8592 1116, grid.261572.5,https://ror.org/047p7y759

Abstract

Understanding how pursuing public climate goals through private processes and actors affects normative commitments to and substantive achievement of North–South climate justice is urgent. The relative role of private actors in climate policy, governance and accountability mechanisms is expanding rapidly. As it has become increasingly clear that implementation of climate policy is falling far short of meeting the Paris Agreement goals, civil society has prevailed on the private sector to adopt climate commitments and engage in private climate governance. And states are using public law and policy to enhance and support private climate governance through green procurement policies, mandatory sustainability or climate disclosure requirements, and similar policies. And, as the impacts of climate change manifest with devastating regularity, in parallel to discussions between states about compensation for loss and damage, efforts to directly impose accountability on private climate actors are proliferating. Most notably, plaintiffs are suing corporate entities directly for climate damages.

Private climate governance and efforts to impose corporate climate accountability have the potential to obscure, erase, and even undermine public commitments to common but differentiated responsibilities and North-South climate justice. This article critically examines one aspect of private climate accountability by using a North-South climate justice lens to evaluate efforts to obtain compensation (court-ordered damages) for climate harms directly from private actors, in particular United States of America (US) carbon majors, alleged to have contributed to climate change (climate damage cases). The article begins by providing background information about global climate change litigation and the US climate damage cases. It then explains why suits seeking climate damages brought by plaintiffs from the Global South, including India, could be less likely to result in the award of enforceable damages against an important subset of particularly culpable and well-resourced defendants, US fossil fuel companies. The application of the doctrines of forum non conveniens and judgment recognition and enforcement by federal courts reticent to disturb the climate policy prerogative of the political branches stand as potential obstacles to recovery for Global South climate plaintiffs. Having shown how and why Global South plaintiffs are less likely to be able to obtain court-ordered compensation directly from US fossil fuel companies that have contributed significantly to climate change and resulting harms, the article concludes by highlighting the climate justice deficits created by differential access to court-ordered compensation from US fossil fuel companies for plaintiffs in the Global North and Global South.

Introduction

Cannupa Hanska Luger’s installation at the Whitney Biennial, Unjziwoslal Wasicuta, ‘the fat-taker’s world is upside down’ in Lakota, is an inverted tipi made of found objects and natural materials. It hangs suspended from the ceiling with the point of the tipi cone facing the floor. The accompanying placard provides the following context:

Cannupa Hanska Luger proposes: “This installation is not inverted . . . our current world is upside down.”1

Recognition that states have common but differentiated responsibilities to mitigate climate change provides the centre of gravity for global efforts to respond to climate change. While the differentiated nature of responsibilities remains contested, countries have accepted the core precepts of common but differentiated responsibilities in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change in 1992, which find a place in the preamble: ‘[T]he largest share of historical and current global emissions of greenhouse gases has originated in developed countries, that per capita emissions in developing countries are still relatively low and that the share of global emissions originating in developing countries will grow to meet their social and development needs.’ Article 3, paragraph 1 then provides:

The Parties should protect the climate system for the benefit of present and future generations of humankind, on the basis of equity and in accordance with their common but differentiated responsibilities and respective capabilities. Accordingly, the developed country Parties should take the lead in combating climate change and the adverse effects thereof.2

In 2015, the world transitioned, in the Paris Agreement, to a bottom-up approach to international climate action, wherein countries set their own commitments through the submission of Nationally Determined Contributions and those commitments are subject to international scrutiny.3 The Paris Agreement reiterated that the concept of common but differentiated responsibilities lies at the centre of evaluating the relative sufficiency of state climate mitigation and adaptation efforts. It exhorts that developed country Parties ‘should continue taking the lead by undertaking economy-wide absolute emission reduction targets,’ while ‘[d]eveloping country Parties should continue enhancing their mitigation efforts, and are encouraged to move over time towards economy-wide emission reduction or limitation targets in the light of different national circumstances’ and repeatedly describes higher expectations for developed country Parties (including explicitly recognising that peaking of greenhouse gas emissions ‘will take longer for developing country Parties’).4 The Nationally Determined Contributions are meant to reflect a Party’s ‘common but differentiated responsibilities and respective capabilities, in the light of different national circumstances.’5

The principle of common but differentiated responsibilities as conceptualised on a North–South axis6 with respect to state responsibility is one aspect of climate justice.7 Commitments to climate justice more broadly—both domestically and viewed internationally through a North–South lens—anchor the development of climate policy, serving as a widely accepted normative imperative.8 ‘[C]limate justice fundamentally is about paying attention to how climate change impacts people differently, unevenly, and disproportionately, as well as redressing the resultant injustices in fair and equitable ways.’9 And, in a North–South context, uneven climate impacts can be traced in large part to colonial and post-colonial history and international economic systems:

[E]nvironmental justice has important North–South dimensions. North–South environmental inequities manifest themselves in the form of distributive, procedural, corrective, and social injustice. The North–South divide is grounded in distributive injustice because the North reaps the economic benefits of natural resource exploitation with little concern for the environmental consequences. Northern excesses have produced potentially irreversible environmental harm that will constrain the development options of present and future generations, particularly in the global South. North–South relations are characterized by procedural injustice because the North dominates decision-making in the World Bank, the IMF, the WTO, and multilateral environmental treaty negotiations. The views of Southern countries are frequently marginalized. North–South relations are marred by corrective injustice because Southern nations (such as the small island developing states facing the imminent loss of their territories due to climate change) have generally been unable to obtain compensation for the North’s prodigious contribution to global environmental degradation or cessation of the offending conduct. Finally, North–South environmental conflicts are reflective of social injustice because they are inextricably intertwined with colonial and post-colonial economic policies that impoverished the global South and facilitated the North’s appropriation of its natural resources.10

Operationalisation of common but differentiated responsibilities and North–South climate justice in public climate law takes myriad forms, ranging from the international climate treaty regime’s demand for developed country leadership and funding, to informing immigration policy.11 While the precise instantiation of these commitments is subject to widely diverging interpretations and significant debate, the core commitments are foundational to public climate policy. Yet, increasingly, climate policy is being implemented through or supplemented by private entities and actors; private climate governance is now recognised as a distinct and important component of the global response to climate change.12 ‘[T]here is a clear trend away from purely intergovernmental policy-making and towards a governance system that incorporates public and private actors at all levels into norm setting, policy-making and norm implementation.’13 It is unclear whether and how commitments to common but differentiated responsibilities and North–South climate justice apply and translate outside of the context of public policy implemented by government actors. Transnational climate governance by non-state actors can be understood to ‘exist as a complement to the multilateral climate change regime’ and thus ‘may be expected to adhere to the main principles and ideas governing the multilateral climate change regime, including the notion that developed countries should lead the efforts in combating climate hanged based on their stronger financial capabilities and their higher level of historical responsibility towards climate change.’14 This raises a fundamental question: How does elevating the importance of private actors in climate policy affect commitments to common but differentiated responsibilities and/or North–South climate justice?

Understanding how pursuing public climate goals through private processes and actors affects normative commitments to and substantive achievement of North–South climate justice is urgent. The relative role of private actors in climate policy, governance and accountability mechanisms are expanding rapidly.15 ‘Some developing countries . . . have expressed the fear that the involvement of private initiatives in mitigation seeks to shift responsibility away from developed countries and is rather imposing additional burdens on developing countries,’ and an empirical analysis from 2016 indicated that transnational climate governance initiatives often failed to reflect explicit North South differentiation.16 As it has become increasingly clear that the implementation of climate policy is falling far short of meeting the Paris Agreement goals, civil society has prevailed on the private sector to adopt climate commitments and engage in private climate governance. States are using public law and policy to enhance and support private climate governance through green procurement policies, mandatory sustainability or climate disclosure requirements, and similar policies.17 The United States’ chief climate mitigation policy, the Inflation Reduction Act, encourages voluntary climate action by private entities through incentives for private sector investment in renewable energy and other climate-friendly technologies.18 Corporate scholars opine,

[U]sing extraterritorial corporate law and governance to promote sustainable corporate governance globally is not all roses. It raises the thorny issue of whether extraterritorial corporate law and governance is merely colonialism repackaged. Climate activists in the Global North may applaud the EU’s use of state-based extraterritorial corporate law and governance to address climate change, human rights, and other sustainability-related issues. However, a recent study by the African Climate Foundation and the London School of Economics’ Firoz Lalji Institute for Africa estimates that one of these well-meaning EU initiatives alone – the EUBorder Carbon Tax– will wipe out 0.91% of Africa’s GDP. This loss to the African economy would be three times the amount of the development cooperation budget that the EU committed to Africa in 2021. This raises a novel question in this new era in which corporate purpose is determined beyond jurisdictional borders: Which country’s (or countries’) purpose is served when the corporate purpose of companies is shaped extraterritorially?19

And, as the impacts of climate change manifest with devastating regularity, in parallel to discussions between states about compensation for loss and damage,20 efforts to directly impose accountability on private climate actors are proliferating. Most notably, plaintiffs are suing corporate entities directly for climate damages.21

Private climate governance and efforts to impose corporate climate accountability have the potential to obscure, erase, and even undermine public commitments to common but differentiated responsibilities and North–South climate justice. The voluntary Science-Based Targets Initiative (SBTi) provides one example.22 The SBTi issues standards that set corporate climate targets based either on a company reducing its emissions at the same rate as the global reduction target (the absolute contraction approach) or meeting decarbonisation goals for a specific industry (the sectorial decarbonisation approach) that SBTi determines is consistent with reductions required to meet the Paris Agreement goals.23 Companies can voluntarily commit to an SBTi target and then show that their conduct is in accordance with the Paris Agreement temperature goals. Importantly, although the SBTi is anchored in consistency with the Paris Agreement and externally marketed as such, the standards and targets that it sets for companies make no meaningful effort to factor in the principle of common but differentiated responsibilities, which in this context would mean that we should expect companies in the Global North to reduce their emissions and decarbonise more and faster than companies in the Global South.

As summarised by one scholar, the absolute contraction approach to setting standards ‘is essentially the equal emissions reduction approach that the Paris Agreement rejected as inconsistent with CBDR [Common But Differentiated Responsibilities]’ and, under the sectoral decarbonisation approach, ‘an electric utility in the U.S. and its Indian counterpart would have the same “science-based” target, requiring the same level of carbon reduction.’24 SBTi erases common but differentiated responsibilities from the private implementation of the international climate change treaty regime. SBTi has enormous influence, covering (as of late 2022) companies with one-third of global market capitalisation, and it is poised to be incorporated into public law—the Biden Administration issued a proposed rule that would require the use of SBTi by federal contractors.25

SBTi is but one example of a growing trend. There are voluntary corporate climate standards, reporting or disclosure requirements of many types, and calls to harmonise these standards across jurisdictions. These are also hardening in many places into public law requirements and being applied extraterritorially to companies in the Global South.26 If, like SBTi, these mechanisms apply the same metrics to companies from the Global North and South, it risks undermining North–South climate justice and eroding the principle of common but differentiated responsibility in the implementation of climate policy.

This article critically examines another aspect of private climate accountability by using a North–South climate justice lens to evaluate efforts to obtain compensation (court-ordered damages) for climate harms directly from private actors, in particular United States (US) carbon majors, alleged to have contributed to climate change (climate damage cases).27 The analysis suggests that this mechanism for imposing private climate accountability could result in an uncomfortable exacerbation of North–South climate injustice. Namely, climate plaintiffs in the Global North may be better positioned to recoup damages from US carbon majors than climate plaintiffs in the Global South, with the practical result that ExxonMobil could be forced to pay for seawalls to protect homes in Marin County but not protect the homes of the 36 million people in India who are expected to endure regular coastal flooding by 2050.28 Given the fact that the Global South’s carbon emissions and wealth are dwarfed by those of the North while it suffers the greatest climate harms, North–South climate justice already resembles Luger’s upside-down world.

This article posits that the increasing emphasis on private climate governance risks exacerbating an already unjust situation because a foundational principle of climate justice and core public policy commitment—CBDR—does not directly apply and often fails to find expression in the context of private climate governance. The article uses the example of the differential in potential damages recovery against private carbon majors by climate plaintiffs in the Global South and Global North. Global South claimants are arguably far more vulnerable to climate harm and deserving of recompense than their US counterparts, yet they face significant additional burdens in gaining access to US courts and enforcement mechanisms.

The article begins by providing background information about global climate change litigation and the US climate damage cases. It then explains why suits seeking climate damages brought by plaintiffs from the Global South, including India, could be less likely to result in the award of enforceable damages against an important subset of particularly culpable and well-resourced defendants, US fossil fuel companies. The application of the doctrines of forum non conveniens and judgment recognition and enforcement by federal courts reticent to disturb the climate policy prerogative of the political branches stand as potential obstacles to recovery for Global South climate plaintiffs. Having shown how and why Global South plaintiffs are less likely to be able to obtain court-ordered compensation directly from US fossil fuel companies that have contributed significantly to climate change and resulting harms, the article concludes by highlighting the climate justice deficits created by differential access to court-ordered compensation from US fossil fuel companies for plaintiffs in the Global North and Global South. Asymmetrical recovery by climate damage plaintiffs in the Global North would invert North–South climate justice, but this outcome can be avoided.

Global climate change litigation and the US climate damage cases

Global climate change litigation

Climate litigation—‘cases before judicial and quasi-judicial bodies that involve material issues of climate change science, policy or law’— has proliferated globally with over 2000 cases filed in 65 jurisdictions as of December 2022.29 Climate suits are far more numerous in the Global North, and particularly in the US, but climate litigation is now a global phenomenon with a growing number of cases brought in the Global South. As of December 2022, there were 1,522 cases filed in the US and 658 in all other jurisdictions. ‘If considering the cases in the United States of America, cases in the Global North represent 89 per cent of the of the total number of climate litigation cases. Cases in the Global South amount to 5.2 per cent while international and regional cases amount to 5.8 per cent.’30

Scholars note that climate cases are tailored to specific jurisdictions and that there are observable regional variations with respect to how cases are styled (cases in the Global South more frequently raise rights-based claims, for example), while also explaining how the legal theories and strategies are in conversation across jurisdictions and that global climate litigation is contributing broadly to transnational climate governance.31 While the precise claims vary widely, the lion’s share of climate litigation is brought by plaintiffs against governments seeking to compel stronger government action on climate change. A much smaller subset of claims seek compensation. Plaintiffs in these cases sue private actors, alleging that they contribute(d) to climate change and, therefore, to harm the plaintiffs who have or will suffer from climate change. Some of these suits seek injunctive relief in the form of a court order requiring the defendant to change its conduct to reduce emissions; others seek damages or a combination of injunctive relief and damages. One notable distinction in climate litigation between jurisdictions is that suits seeking compensation (court-ordered damages) for climate harms from private actors alleged to have contributed to climate change (climate damage cases) are far more common in the US.32 Over twenty-five climate damage cases have been brought by US plaintiffs in the US courts against US and foreign corporations, primarily large energy companies, with new cases being filed rapidly.33

There are relatively few climate damage cases in the rest of the world. Most of the cases outside of the US seek damages for illegal harm to a natural resource that exacerbates climate change by destroying a carbon sink, such as through illegal deforestation. While harms from climate change constitute one element of the damage calculation in these cases, the underlying unlawful conduct is not a contribution to climate change per se. For example, between 2012 and 2019, Indonesia successfully obtained climate damages from palm oil producers for destroying peatland in part because the peatland constituted a carbon sink and its destruction exacerbated climate change; ‘climate damages arising from GHG emissions were calculated by assigning a numerical value to the cost of emitting a unit of carbon, then calculating the units of carbon emitted by a corporation’s action.’34 Similarly, Brazil’s Federal Environment Agency has filed public civil actions against entities engaged in illegal deforestation and obtained compensation that includes damages for the exacerbation of climate change from the reduction of forest sequestration.35

There are other transnational cases that implicate climate change without directly seeking damages for the harms from climate change. For example, in the case of Survival International Italia (on behalf of the Ayoreo Totobiegosode Indigenous People) v Pasubio, a lawsuit was filed by an Italian NGO against Pasubio, an Italian leather company supplying firms like BMW and Land Rover.36 The plaintiffs allege that Pasubio violated the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises by sourcing leather from cattle ranching firms operating in the Gran Chaco forests, home to the Ayoreo Totobiegosode. The suit claims that these activities contribute to deforestation and the violation of the Ayoreo’s human rights. This case addresses the link between deforestation and the climate emergency.

A few climate damage cases outside of the US seek damages where the underlying conduct alleged to be unlawful is directly the contribution to climate change.37 In March 2024, a farmer in Belgium sued the largest refiner and distributor in Belgium, a transnational corporation TotalEnergies, seeking damages for climate harms to his farm and injunctive relief.38 There are only two discovered cases in which a plaintiff in the Global South has sued a private defendant in the Global North for climate damages.

In Luciano Lliuya v RWE AG, a Peruvian farmer filed a suit at the Regional Court of Essen, Germany, against RWE AG, Germany’s largest energy corporation. The plaintiff alleged that the city of Huaraz faced a significant flood risk from Lake Palcacocha, attributed to the melting of the Palcaraju glacier, exacerbated by GHG emissions.39 The claimant sought damages to cover the cost of preventative measures against flooding, proportionate to RWE's 0.47% contribution to global GHG emissions.40 The case marked a historic moment with its preliminary finding and advancement to the discovery and evidence phase, with court-appointed judges and experts visiting Peru to assess the risk and damage posed by the melting glacier.41

In Asmania et al. vs Holcim, four inhabitants of the Indonesian island of Pari filed a lawsuit in a Swiss court against Holcim, a Swiss-based major building materials company.42 The suit was brought under the infringement of personal rights, as provided by Article 28 of the Swiss Civil Code and sought redress for unjust harm under Article 41 of the Swiss Code of Obligations. The plaintiffs demanded a 43% reduction in carbon emissions by 2030 and a 69% reduction by 2040. Additionally, similar to the Luciano Lliuya case, they sought compensation proportional to Holcim’s contribution to carbon emissions for climate-related damages suffered by Pari, to fund adaptation measures.43

There is no discovered climate damage case brought by a foreign plaintiff (from the Global North or the Global South) against a private US defendant.

US climate damage cases

Plaintiffs in the US have sued or are suing corporate entities for conduct that they allege worsens or has worsened climate change, typically the combustion or extraction and sale of fossil fuels. The plaintiffs allege a range of harms from climate change, including everything from the closure of crab fisheries when climate-warmed waters cause algal outbreaks that contaminate crabs with domoic acid, to the costs of fortifying public infrastructure against sea level rise and ‘implementing costly heat resiliency measures, such as cooling centres and green infrastructure that reduces urban heat islands.’44 The plaintiffs seek damages and often also injunctive relief from the defendant corporations to remedy these harms.45 Early climate damage suits were often brought against large direct emitters, such as energy companies operating coal-fired power plants, and the key cause of action sounded in the federal common law of public nuisance. Through a process of strategic evolution driven by intervening court decisions, the climate damage suits presently pending are brought against large fossil fuel producers, including US companies such as Exxon Mobil Corporation (ExxonMobil), Chevron, and Conoco Phillips, and the key causes of action sound in state law, often state common law public nuisance, product liability, and/or state consumer protection statutes. While the contours of these doctrines and the plaintiffs’ precise allegations differ between states and across cases, the core conduct alleged to be unlawful is that the defendant companies contributed to climate change by selling fossil fuels without disclosing (or actively dissembling about) the climate harms from the combustion of those fossil fuels.

The plaintiffs in these cases are all located in the US. If the plaintiffs succeed, the damages awarded would be used to enhance adaptation in the US and compensate individuals in the US harmed by climate change. Yet the conduct alleged to be unlawful exacerbated climate harm around the world. Even fossil fuels exclusively American in provenance, distribution, and use—in that they were extracted, sold, and combusted solely within the US—exacerbated climate change and harm from climate change worldwide. Moreover, many of the defendants engaged in the same or similar conduct in myriad non-US jurisdictions, including in the Global South, through the extraction, refinement, and sale of fossil fuels in those non-US jurisdictions, and the conduct and impact of the sprawling climate disinformation campaign likewise crossed borders.

Based solely on a consideration of the conduct and harm and viewed through a corrective justice lens, non-US climate plaintiffs would seem to be as deserving of compensation as US plaintiffs. Coupled with considerations of North–South climate justice and distributive justice, non-US plaintiffs from the Global South would seem to be far more deserving of compensation. However, for the reasons described below, the ability of climate plaintiffs in the Global South to collect meaningful damages from US fossil fuel companies will be largely dependent on the treatment of their claims by US courts. And, for a variety of reasons, it may be difficult for a plaintiff in the Global South to obtain damages for climate harms from US corporate climate defendants, perhaps more so than for a plaintiff in the US.

Gatekeeping by US courts

The US courts’ gatekeeping control over the ability of Global South climate plaintiffs to obtain damages from US corporate climate defendants results from a complex interplay of history (in part colonial) and economic and political systems; the geographic distribution of key fossil fuel defendants’ assets; and the interstices of legal (primarily procedural) doctrines that determine when foreign plaintiffs can bring their claims in US courts and when judgments obtained outside of the US can be enforced by US courts. Three US fossil fuel companies—Chevron, ExxonMobil, and Conoco Phillips—are responsible for nearly eight per cent of global emissions for the period 1750-2010.46 While these companies operate around the world, they are incorporated and headquartered in the US and have few assets in many Global South countries that are highly vulnerable to climate change, such as India.47 In 2023, Chevron, ExxonMobil, and Conoco Phillips reported combined earnings of 68.4 billion dollars.48 The US fossil fuel industry, most notably ExxonMobil, led the organised climate disinformation campaign and remains hostile to government interventions to address climate change and reduce emissions.49 These US carbon majors are thus uniquely important as potential defendants in climate damage suits by virtue of their outsized contribution to climate change, deep-pockets, and culpable conduct. And, notably, the climate impact and assets of these companies reflect, in no small part, the advantages they continue to enjoy as beneficiaries of global political and economic systems rooted in a history of colonialism.50

Here, then, are the facts on the ground. US climate damage plaintiffs have survived numerous threshold challenges to the justiciability of their cases and now seem poised to have their claims heard on the merits, making more real the possibility that US climate change plaintiffs may succeed in obtaining damage awards from one or more corporate climate defendants. US corporate climate defendants significantly contribute to even more severe climate harms in the Global South51 and are a potentially important source of compensation for Global South climate plaintiffs. But obtaining court-ordered compensation from some of the most significant (culpable and well-resourced) defendants may well require Global South plaintiffs to get permission from US courts, either to allow their cases to proceed in US courts or to enforce judgments obtained elsewhere. For climate damage plaintiffs from the Global South, US courts thus hold the proverbial key to the coffers.

In 2017, scholars Michael Byers, Kelsey Franks, and Andrew Gage published an article, The Internalization of Climate Damages Litigation, that describes the key procedural considerations (jurisdiction, choice of law, and recognition and enforcement of judgments) that govern whether and how foreign plaintiffs might obtain damages from US corporate climate defendants.52 The discussion that follows builds on this work by updating the analysis related to two key procedural hurdles for Global South climate plaintiffs—forum non conveniens and judgment recognition and enforcement—in light of subsequent legal developments. Since there is ample room for judicial discretion in the application of these doctrines, federal courts in the US, long wary of judicial interference with climate policy, may be inclined to use these doctrines to rebuff efforts by Global South climate plaintiffs to obtain compensation from US climate defendants.

Forum Non Conveniens

One way for climate plaintiffs from the Global South to seek damages from the US corporate climate defendants would be to sue those defendants in US courts. For strategic reasons, US climate plaintiffs are pressing their claims in state courts under state law. Climate plaintiffs from the Global South will likely not have the option of proceeding in state court, as the cases would likely be removable to federal court on the grounds of diversity of citizenship.53 That the climate defendants in the lawsuits brought by US climate plaintiffs have spent the last four years litigating (unsuccessfully) to remove the cases from state to federal court suggests that they would likely remove any case brought by a Global South plaintiff.54 Proceeding in federal court could negatively affect the plaintiffs’ prospects. While Global South plaintiffs could still seek to assert claims sounding in state law (or even in the law of a foreign jurisdiction) in federal court, one federal circuit, as described in more detail below, has held that climate tort claims, even if pleaded as state law claims by plaintiffs, are necessarily governed by the federal common law and are either displaced by the federal Clean Air Act or preempted under dormant foreign affairs preemption.55 Climate plaintiffs from the Global South would thus likely be unable to avail themselves of a key strategic manoeuvre of US climate plaintiffs—proceeding in state court under state law theories—which could result in the dismissal of their claims.

Climate defendants could further seek to have the claims of Global South climate plaintiffs dismissed under the doctrine of forum non conveniens. The purpose of the present analysis is not to thoroughly explore the law of forum non conveniens; estimate with precision the likelihood that Global South plaintiffs could resist motions to dismiss for forum non conveniens; or suggest creative strategies for how they might do so. For the present analysis, what matters is that the application of the doctrine of forum non conveniens is sufficiently open-ended to give courts wide discretion. And, as explained further infra, there are reasons to believe that federal courts will be inclined to exercise their discretion to avoid hearing Global South plaintiffs’ claims. For this reason, forum non conveniens could pose a not-insignificant obstacle for Global South plaintiffs seeking to bring climate damage claims against US corporations in US courts.

A brief overview of forum non conveniens illustrates the wide discretion that it gives courts to dismiss actions, particularly when brought by foreign plaintiffs.

A district court may exercise its discretion and dismiss a case for forum non conveniens when (1) “an alternative forum has jurisdiction to hear [the] case” and (2) trial in the chosen forum would prove, disproportionate to the plaintiff's convenience, oppressive and vexatious to the defendant; or “the chosen forum [is] inappropriate because of considerations affecting the court's own administrative and legal problems.”56

It is typically not difficult for defendants seeking to have a case dismissed to establish that an alternative forum exists; ‘although U.S. courts apply varying standards of foreign judicial adequacy when deciding forum non conveniens motions, they are uniformly lenient, making it easy in most cases for a defendant to establish that the foreign judiciary is sufficiently adequate to allow dismissal.’57

With respect to the second prong, courts balance the private and public interest factors of proceeding in the alternative forum. The US Supreme Court has identified a non-exhaustive list of public interest factors that courts should balance and some of these could support the dismissal of Global South plaintiffs’ claims, such as consideration of

the local interest in having localized controversies decided at home; the interest in having the trial of a diversity case in a forum that is at home with the law that must govern the action [and] [a]voidance of unnecessary problems in conflict of laws, or in the application of foreign law.58

Importantly, ‘in a forum non conveniens analysis, the public interests favour dismissal not just when a court has to apply foreign law, but also, when the court would be required to untangle problems in conflict of laws.’59 Courts have further reasoned that in a personal injury case, ‘the country where the injury occurred has a strong interest in enforcing its laws to obtain justice for the injured party,’60 and this rationale could be readily extended to climate injuries. While there is typically a presumption in favour of the plaintiff’s choice of forum in forum non conveniens analysis, ‘a foreign plaintiff's choice deserves less deference.’61 Indeed, US district court dismissals for forum non conveniens are common (granted at a rate of approximately 50% overall) and even more common for foreign plaintiffs (60%).62

Courts emphasise that ‘the ultimate inquiry is where trial will best serve the convenience of the parties and the ends of justice.’63 The forum non conveniens determination is thus a ‘fact-intensive, multifactor analysis’ that invites district court judges to impose their own Rorschach-imprimatur on the case which is then subject to review on appeal only for clear abuse of discretion.64 And learned commentators concede that ‘many defendants can employ forum non conveniens to engage in “reverse forum shopping’’ to eliminate the plaintiff's lawsuit because it is unlikely that the case will be recommenced in the foreign court’ and one ‘survey of 85 cases dismissed in favor or a foreign court showed that every case was either abandoned or settled for a nominal amount.’65

Judgment recognition and enforcement doctrine

Global South climate plaintiffs could, instead, bring their claims to their home jurisdictions, either initially or upon dismissal under forum non conveniens. Obtaining a large damages judgment against a US climate defendant may prove difficult; it has long been recognised that countries in the Global South may be wary of imposing large judgments on Global North companies for fear of chilling investment66—‘the political economy of some Global South countries—including the dependence on resource-hungry multinationals for investment—can make the local administration of justice difficult where significant investors appear as defendants.’67 But even if Global South plaintiffs win a judgment for damages against the US climate defendant in a foreign court, they may struggle to enforce the judgment. The US climate defendant may lack sufficient assets in the jurisdiction of the court that orders damages, which could cause Global South climate plaintiffs to seek to enforce judgment in US courts. And, as with forum non conveniens, judgment recognition and enforcement doctrine involve numerous, often complicated, considerations that leave significant room for judicial discretion.

Judgement recognition and enforcement doctrine in the US apply state law, even in federal court, based on the 1962 Uniform Foreign Money Judgment Recognition Act, the 2005 Uniform Foreign-Country Money Judgments Recognition Act, or common law principles.68 A judgment must not be recognised if the court determines that it was rendered in a judicial system that does not satisfy due process requirements or that the foreign court lacked personal or subject matter jurisdiction.69 Courts also have permissive discretion to deny recognition of a judgment in numerous circumstances, including if the court determines that the judgment was obtained by fraud, the claim for relief is repugnant to public policy, or the foreign court was an inconvenient forum (where jurisdiction was based on personal service).70 The 2005 Uniform Foreign-Country Money Judgments Recognition Act further invites courts to decline to recognise a judgment where ‘the judgment was rendered in circumstances that raise substantial doubt about the integrity of the court with respect to the judgment; or . . . the specific proceeding in the foreign court leading to the judgment was not compatible with the requirements of due process of law.’71

Importantly, even where a US court has previously determined that a foreign jurisdiction provided an alternate adequate forum sufficient to dismiss for forum non conveniens, a US court could later decline to enforce the judgment based on perceived limitations in the foreign judiciary, creating what has been termed a ‘transnational access-to-justice gap’,72

Due to differences between the forum non conveniens doctrine and the judgment enforcement doctrine, it is possible to argue consistently that a foreign court is available, adequate, and more appropriate for dismissal purposes but suffers from inadequacies that preclude enforcement. Among other differences, the forum non conveniens doctrine’s foreign judicial adequacy standard is lenient, plaintiff-focused, and ex ante, whereas the judgment enforcement doctrine's standard is stricter, defendant-focused, and ex post. Thus, a U.S. court may dismiss a suit in favor of a foreign judiciary because it is adequate under the forum non conveniens doctrine's standard but refuse to enforce a resulting foreign judgment because the same foreign judiciary is not sufficiently adequate for enforcement under the judgment enforcement doctrine's standard. . .. The problem is that this type of interaction between the forum non conveniens doctrine and the judgment enforcement doctrine can produce a transnational access-to-justice gap. Access to justice requires not only court access, but also a potential remedy. . .. This problem is especially acute when the defendant lacks assets within the foreign court's jurisdiction, as will often be the case when the defendant is not based there. Under these circumstances, the only way to obtain a remedy may be by enforcement against the assets of the defendant in the United States.73

The issue of judgment enforcement is particularly salient for plaintiffs in the Global South as US climate defendants may have few in-country assets against which a judgment can be enforced. Scholars note that transnational corporations are aware of the limitations on enforcement and may use that as a bargaining chip in negotiating low settlements. In an article critiquing the settlement of claims after the Bhopal disaster, one scholar observed that

[f]or . . . any transnational, the issue of enforcement can be a powerful bargaining chip when attempting to reach an advantageous settlement. India, or any developing country, cannot necessarily expect that a seizure of the company's assets within its borders will easily satisfy the corporation's debt, or provide any substantial threat that will force the transnational to pay up.74

Global South climate damage plaintiffs who obtain judgments against US climate defendants in foreign courts may seek to have those judgments enforced in US courts. However, similarly to the doctrine of forum non conveniens, the law relating to the enforcement of foreign judgments in the US leaves significant room for the exercise of judicial discretion and there are numerous examples, including in the environmental context, where foreign plaintiffs have been unable to collect on judgments issued in foreign jurisdictions against US corporations.75

Federal court reticence

Reasonable application of the forum non conveniens and judgment enforcement doctrines to a well-pleaded case with the right facts could well result in a court allowing a case to proceed in the US or a foreign-obtained judgment to be enforced in the US. Within both doctrines, there is room for courts in the US to exercise their gatekeeping function to open the gates to climate plaintiffs from the Global South. There are, however, reasons to be doubtful that US courts will do so.

Even with respect to US climate plaintiffs, federal courts in the US evidence deep reticence to accept jurisdiction and reach the merits in cases that they perceive as intersecting with climate policy in ways that could undermine the power of the legislature to set climate policy and thus overstep the role of the judiciary. Federal district courts often dismissed early climate damage cases as presenting nonjusticiable political questions and the Supreme Court ultimately held that the Clean Air Act displaced federal common law actions against large US emitters. Even if they were able to convince a court not to apply forum non conveniens, and to allow them to proceed in US courts, plaintiffs from the Global South may not have the possibility of proceeding in state courts under state law. Cases brought by Global South plaintiffs would likely be removable to federal court based on diversity of citizenship. Once removed, even if the cases plead only state law claims, their claims could be dismissed as displaced under the holding in AEP v Connecticut.76 This was the result in City of New York v Chevron Corporation, where the Second Circuit held that most of the City of New York’s tort claims necessarily sounded in federal common law and were therefore displaced under the federal Clean Air Act per the Supreme Court’s holding in AEP v Connecticut.77 Although the City alleged tort claims under the state common law of New York, the Second Circuit reasoned: ‘Stripped to its essence . . . the question before us is whether a nuisance suit seeking to recover damages for the harms caused by global greenhouse gas emissions may proceed under New York law. Our answer is simple: no.78

And it seems possible, if not likely, that federal courts in the US would find a reason not to hear (or, in the case of an application to enforce a foreign judgment, enforce) Global South plaintiffs’ climate damage claims. Even where a Global South plaintiff’s climate damage suit was not held to be displaced—because it was brought under state law or the law of the Global South jurisdiction—and was permitted to proceed in the US, a federal court could find other grounds for deeming the claim nonjusticiable. In City of New York v Chevron Corporation, the Second Circuit also dismissed New York City’s claims that were based on emissions from outside the US despite holding that those claims were not displaced by the Clean Air Act, which it ruled did not apply extraterritorially. The Court held that, while not displaced by the federal Clean Air Act, federal common law tort claims for emissions outside of the United States were not justiciable because applying federal common law extraterritorially to emissions outside of the US would too greatly interfere with foreign affairs. The Court’s reasoning, excerpted at length below, reveals the reticence of US courts to take up cases that they perceive as usurping Congress’ role in setting US international climate policy:

[W]e conclude that foreign policy concerns foreclose New York's proposal here to recognize a federal common law cause of action targeting emissions emanating from beyond our national borders. . ..

To hold the Producers accountable for purely foreign activity (especially the Foreign Producers) would require them to internalize the costs of climate change and would presumably affect the price and production of fossil fuels abroad. It would also bypass the various diplomatic channels that the United States uses to address this issue, such as the U.N. Framework and the Paris Agreement.

Such an outcome would obviously sow confusion and needlessly complicate the nation's foreign policy, while clearly infringing on the prerogatives of the political branches. . . .. [C]ondoning an extraterritorial nuisance action here would not only risk jeopardizing our nation's foreign policy goals but would also seem to circumvent Congress's own expectations and carefully balanced scheme of international cooperation on a topic of global concern. . ..

We therefore agree with the district court that any federal common law claim against the Producers that is not displaced by the Clean Air Act nonetheless still fails under the reasoning supplied by Kiobel and Jesner and the need for judicial caution in the face of delicate foreign policy considerations.79

To summarise, Global South plaintiffs would likely end up in federal court; federal courts have demonstrated marked reticence to involve the federal judiciary in climate controversies that they view as having significant implications for federal and global climate policy; and the doctrines that federal courts would apply to determine whether Global South climate plaintiffs can obtain recourse through the US court system and provide plausible doctrinal reasons for federal courts to avoid hearing the claims of or enforcing judgments obtained by plaintiffs from the Global South. It is legally possible for Global South plaintiffs to sue and obtain damage judgments against US fossil fuel defendants. But, as compared to US climate damage plaintiffs, plaintiffs from the Global South face significant practical and procedural headwinds, which should raise concerns about the North–South justice implications of corporate climate accountability.

Climate justice deficits

Application of the current doctrines that govern hearing foreign claims and enforcing foreign judgments in US courts could lead to a result that would offend North–South climate justice: Asymmetrical climate damage recovery where US climate plaintiffs obtain compensation for their climate harms from US carbon majors while plaintiffs from the Global South cannot. This outcome would be substantively and highly unjust—an inversion of North–South climate justice. Residents of the US, already overall better equipped to adapt through geographic accident and economic development fuelled in part by high emissions and a fossil fuel economy, would sequester even more adaptive resources, gilding the lily of an already enhanced adaptive capacity. An even greater North-favouring asymmetry could be imagined: Some have proposed that US plaintiffs sue emitters in India.80

While North-favouring asymmetrical climate damage recovery is a real possibility/risk, there are some reasons to think that it is unlikely to manifest. First, the cases brought by US plaintiffs against the US carbon majors may fail. In that case, the inability of Global South plaintiffs to obtain damages is, while still unjust, not such a stark inversion of North–South climate justice. Strong arguments can be made that the US fossil fuel companies’ wrongdoing—from a corrective justice perspective—is even more pronounced with respect to Global South plaintiffs. The fossil fuel companies were well aware that the impacts of climate change would manifest first and most severely in the Global South.

Second, there could, at least theoretically, be an asymmetrical recovery in the opposite direction—there are paths through which Global South climate damage plaintiffs might succeed in obtaining climate damages from US carbon majors even where US plaintiffs cannot. If the climate damage claims fail on the merits under US law, plaintiffs from the Global South may even have an advantage—an additional opportunity to recover—because they can argue on the choice of law grounds that the law of their home jurisdiction should govern the dispute. The law in some countries may be more favourable to climate damage plaintiffs than the law in the US.81

For instance, in India the ‘right to a clean environment’82 and the ‘right to be free from the adverse effects of climate change’83 have been recognised as a fundamental right by the Supreme Court. Additionally, industries engaged in hazardous or inherently dangerous activities are subject to the doctrine of absolute liability, meaning they can be held liable for harm resulting from their activities, regardless of intent or negligence.84 This unique provision provides a significant advantage for plaintiffs from India, particularly in cases involving corporate actors in mining, chemical manufacturing, or heavy industries, who can be held accountable for their contributions to climate change. This legal framework may offer plaintiffs from India a more favourable path to recovery compared to US plaintiffs, where similar climate damage claims might face greater hurdles under US law.85

But a reality check. For this to occur, either a US court would have to apply the law of a Global South country to order an industry-altering damage judgment against a US carbon major or a US court would have to enforce an industry-altering damage judgment produced by a court in the Global South against a US carbon major—against the backdrop of US plaintiffs being unable to obtain damages. Even if the judiciary would do so (and recall the various ‘outs’—the forum non conveniens and judgment enforcement doctrines), US fossil fuel defendants could still lobby Congress seeking legislative liability protection—i.e., a law immunising them from damage claims. The fossil fuel industry has often lobbied for such liability protection, often in the context of negotiations over the adoption of climate law.

Climate damage plaintiffs from the Global South could also sue or seek to enforce a judgment obtained in their home jurisdiction against US climate defendants in other jurisdictions, in particular jurisdictions where the US climate defendants (or a subsidiary) have significant assets.86 And some US climate defendants will have some assets in Global South jurisdictions that could support the enforcement of a judgment.

However, even if the inversion of North–South climate justice in the form of asymmetrical North-favouring recovery does not in fact manifest, recognising the possibility and risk that the existing legal system allows (if not invites) this result highlights the extent to which achieving North–South climate justice requires affirmative work to recognise and correct underlying systems that perpetuate North–South injustice. Once we recognise the systemic contribution to injustice, we can also see ways to correct it.

In the present context, the easiest correction may simply be to equip advocates to frame arguments that persuade judges in the US to be mindful of the implications for justice when evaluating climate damage claims brought by Global South plaintiffs. For example, a court resolving a motion to dismiss a climate damage claim brought by a Global South plaintiff on the grounds of forum non conveniens could impose (a) condition(s) on the dismissal, for example condition dismissal on the defendant's consent to the exercise of personal jurisdiction by a foreign court and/or on the defendant's agreement to satisfy any foreign judgment entered against it.87 Indeed, some circuits might require that a court ‘impose conditions if there is a justifiable reason to doubt that a party will cooperate with the foreign forum.’88 In Carijano v Occidental Petroleum Corporation, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals held that a district court abused its discretion by dismissing a claim brought by Peruvian plaintiffs and an American non-governmental organization for forum non conveniens without imposing as a condition that Occidental would satisfy a Peruvian judgment, observing that ‘[w]hen there is reason to think that enforcing a judgment in a foreign country would be problematic, courts have required assurances that a defendant will satisfy any judgment as a condition to a forum non conveniens dismissal.’89

Additionally, as jurisdictions contemplate adopting climate compensation legislation,90 they should be mindful about structuring such legislation to avoid North-favouring asymmetrical recovery. (Jurisdictions might even consider honouring North–South climate justice by adopting rules that produce South-favouring asymmetrical recovery.) While this article focuses on damage remedies, significant North–South justice issues may attend requests for injunctive relief as well. As explained eloquently by Kim Bouwer,

it is not clear that seeking to shut down fossil fuel operations—a significant source of revenue for African countries—is necessarily consistent with climate justice. This reflects a universalizing perception of what is required in the climate response, which is not necessarily consistent with the contribution that is required by African states.91

Conclusion

In late June of 2021, a climate change-fuelled heat wave hit the Pacific Northwest. For several days, temperatures broke records, in many places exceeding a prior high-temperature records by 5°C.92 In Multnomah County, Oregon (US), 69 people died from hypothermia and deaths from all causes doubled.93 In 2023, Multnomah County sued select fossil fuel companies, including US carbon majors ExxonMobil, Chevron, and Conoco Phillips, seeking $1.55 billion in climate change damages for ‘the costs of actions Multnomah County has already taken, expenditures made, and losses incurred to protect the public health, safety, and property of the County and its residents from extreme heat weather events and wildfire smoke’94 and $50 billion for an abatement fund to provide ‘resources necessary to adequately prepare the County and its citizens for a new normal—heat domes, blocking events, periods of high heat and/or wildfire so severe that they kill and sicken inhabitants, destroy property, and weaken—sometimes cripple—critical infrastructure’ including:

renovating buildings to withstand extreme heat, fitting cooling units into buildings, providing cooling units in the community, providing additional cooling shelters for heat emergencies, installing air filtration systems, planting of greenspaces to reduce the temperature in heat islands, reroofing buildings with materials that better manage heat, repave roads and fortify bridges.95

Climate change-fuelled heatwaves hit communities in India with regularity. In 2003, a heatwave caused more than 3000 deaths in Andhra Pradesh and, in May 2010, a heatwave in Ahmedabad (Gujarat) caused approximately 1300 deaths.96 Scientists estimate that around 1116 deaths annually in India were attributed to heatwaves in the period 2008-2019,97 and there is concern that parts of India have or soon will experience heat conditions (‘wet bulb’ temperatures) that exceed the human survivability threshold.98 Like Multnomah County, Ahmedabad is working hard to protect its citizens. In 2013, Ahmedabad engaged in an extensive process, working with an international partnership, to prepare India’s first heat action plan. The heat action plan prioritises low-cost preparations for extreme heat, including community education, early warning systems, and enhancements to health care capacity.99 Ahmedabad regularly updates the plan, and studies suggest that it has effectively reduced heat deaths.100 But advocates fear that more involved measures, including changes to Ahmedabad’s built environment, may be necessary as temperatures continue to rise.101 Developing heat action plans and other interventions to deal with heatwaves across India will require significant resources.

Yet, Ahmedabad has not sued the US carbon majors, and likely has to persuade US courts either that US courts are a suitable forum to entertain Ahmedabad’s claims or that US courts should enforce a judgment that Ahmedabad obtains in India. This sits uncomfortably next to the facts and principles that animate North–South climate justice. India has contributed far less to climate change than the US and benefited far less from fossil fuel capitalism. By accident of geographic fate, it will experience more and earlier severe climate impacts. By historical (colonial) design, perpetuated by modern international economic and governance systems, it does not have nearly the resources of the US—economic, institutional, infrastructure—to adapt. The ‘burden of disease associated with extreme heat is particularly pronounced in Low and Middle-Income Countries . . . such as India, where extreme environmental exposures intersect with unplanned urbanization, poor-quality housing, declining urban green cover and other vulnerabilities in the world’s most populous country.’102 Yet there is far less research about heat waves and their impact in countries in the Global South. Meanwhile, India faces pressure to cool its population without increasing the energy demand and emissions associated with an increased use of air conditioners.103

Cannupa Hanksa Luger has it right . . . ‘our current world is upside down.’104
